replies.context:
Yes, global warming is a byproduct.  The process by which enzymes break down waste, whether artificial or organic, gives off plenty of heat energy.

If it were up to me, I would just burn it and release as much carbon-based gas into the atmosphere as possible and use the heat generated from that to run electricity-generating turbines.  There is less heat retained at ground level from greenhouse gases than is generated by enzymatic digestion at the levels needed to eliminate all the plastic waste presently out there.  Plus, carbon gases eventually all fall back to earth due to their weight, where they turn back into other organics, like fossil fuels.
Thank you.

While municipalities have gotten better, I remember a news story where they were showing the recycling trucks coming into the landfill and unloading in the same pile as the garbage trucks were.  No recycling was being done.  The story upset a lot of residents since they had to pay an increase in garbage collection for 'recycling' that wasn't being done.
obviously the "news" story missed the part where the recycle truck loads were first sorted with UNrecycables reloaded and sent to the dump. And you missed it too...

It's not likely YOU were standing there when the R/C trucks were 'reloaded.' The problem your retort faces is that there's an exceptionally limited market for R/C glass and plastics. R/C collections of those materials far exceeds the market for their re-use in other products. All over the country loads of plastic and glass go directly into disposal because there's NO market for them. But, no worry. Taxpayers pay 'put-or-pay' service fees for a service that continues to be pointless to anyone (and to the environment) if they're not making $$ from providing the service.

the problem with your retort is that generalizations aren't facts.
The REAL and primary issue with home recycling is the consumers do such a poor job of sorting, tossing non recyclables with recyclable and causing contamination at the sort facility. It is widely known that plastic recycling is miniscule, so the first principle, ignored by a consumer society and industry, is to REDUCE and REUSE. But why do that when the cost of doing such can be socialized. Glass and metal do indeed have decent markets, it is plastics that are the worst, though there are some programs, like Ridwell, that are making a difference locally and companies like Driscolls taking back their plastic clamshells for reuse.
Taxpayers and all of humanity pay one way or the other. The underlying issue is economic. Everyone on Earth is free to pollute the air, land and ocean foisting the cost to the planet.
The true cost of any human activity rarely includes the cost of waste as externalizing that cost increases the profit.

And so, Lycopine, you complain that "generalizations aren't facts" and then proceed to generalize using unsupported claims blaming the public's selection of alternative processes. The reason "plastic recycling is miniscule" is that the cost of recycling plastic waste (and some other commonly collected materials) for use in many products is as high, or greater, than producing new plastics for them. Please don't try to re-hash "Tragedy of the Commons" for me. The underlying reason R/C hasn't made substantial gains over its status quo in the ~40years its been institutionalized is it's NEVER paid for itself (as was advertised it would when the policies were adopted). Without major waste haulers benefitting from 'put-or-pay' fees for collection & sorting (taking BILLIONS out of the pockets of the public; who NEVER benefit from their purchase of the service) only the materials that had well developed markets for them back before R/C's start-up would be getting collected. The entire R/C policy is effectively a social cult activity that continues because it makes $$$ for the major waste haulers who effect the policy.
while CANCER-vative job creation is to dump all toxic waste in the ocean at the lowest possible cost to maximize profits and socialize expenses...
